body:
Angkor, Part 2

The weather in Cambodia is terribly hot and humid even now, the coolest time of the year. We started our tomb raiding at daybreak and couldn’t tolerate the sun byÂ 11 AM. Here are some more pictures.

Angkor, Part 1

Angkor, near Siem Reap, Cambodia was the capital city of the Khmer empire, which lasted from 802 AD to 1351. It is the number one tourist destination in southeast Asia.

Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom are the most well-known temples and it seems like a big deal to arrive early and watch the sunrise over Angkor Wat. In our opinion it wasn’t worth it except to admire the tourist hordes of which we were a part. After the overrated sunrise we explored Angkors Wat and Thom along with the crowds. I think the majority was Chinese.

Angkor offers many more ruins to explore away from the groups of 1-day package tourists. Many sites have tumbled and crumbled and been reclaimed by the jungle giving them a very Indiana Jones or Tomb Raider feel.

Siem Reap, Cambodia

Due to itinerary adjustments we might not get to see much of Cambodia, but because Angkor is the number 1 tourist destination in Southeast Asia we decided to take a side trip from Bangkok. The bus journey takes about 8 hours, including border crossing. It was rather uneventful except at the Cambodia visa office the officials tried to charge us the official $20 visa fee plus an extra 100 baht (about $3). Posted on window was a rather unprofessional handwritten sign stating: Visa USD $20 + 100 baht. Having done our research already we knew this was a scam, so Peter simply shoved our paperwork plus $20 at them and repeated “No, twenty dollars only!” about 3 times and they took it without issue.

A few observations on Siem Reap. It’s tourist land. Cambodia is a very poor country and you can see it from the bus. You can see farms and fields and people living rural lives. The roads are dirt and buildings utilitarian. There is more trash on the side of the road than in Thailand (though less than India.) But once you pull up in Siem Reap there are neon lights, paved roads, and beautiful hotels. Siem Reap offers everything you expect from over-touristed places: souvenir shops, cheap massages, fish pedicures, happy hour deals, and pizza restaurants. Overly friendly and aggressive people selling stuff to you on the street from tuk tuk rides to drugs. The locals speak English alarmingly well (and Mandarin too.) Rowdy tourists from all over the world spill into the streets: Australians, Europeans, Russians, the hordes of Chinese, and Koreans. It can be fun if you set your expectations accordingly. Don’t expect the authentic Cambodian experience in Siem Reap, just go have a $1.50 margarita and enjoy the ridiculous “spring break” atmosphere.

Cambodian Cooking Class

Although we usually don’t drop names in our blog, I am going to mention the cooking class I took in Siem Reap. Le Tigre de Papier is a restaurant and offers a wonderful cooking class for $14. You can pick any appetizer, main, and dessert FROM THEIR MENU and cook it yourself! I chose to make fresh spring rolls, shrimp amok, and mango and sticky rice. The class started with a tour of a local market introducing us to the different ingredients we would use. The instructor was very sweet and entertaining, and I was amazed how she could juggle 9 people cooking different things while maintaing a very personal level of instruction for each person. This was a great experience, extremely affordable, and I definitely recommend it!

photos.caption: food stalls at the night market

body:
Bangkok Night Market

Somehow we let a few days slip by on Koh Lanta, and spent a quiet new year on the beach. Then we finally got back in gear and headed to Bangkok.

We have heard it was crazy and noisy, but we don’t think so. Bangkok is quite easy to travel around. With a multitude of modern rail options and a go-with-the-flow bus system, we could always reach our destination. Yes it’s hot and humid, but there are so many malls and convenience stores everywhere where you can pop in and get a blast of AC.

There is always something tasty and cheap wherever you go, so you never have to worry about getting hungry. This is very important! Bangkok is all about food, and it’s delicious!

We visited some night markets crammed with goodies, edible and not. Don’t listen to people when they say Americans eat a lot and are too consumerist - in my experience Asians own these things. Night markets are all about teh gluttony and materialism! Grilled meat on a stick! Squid on a stick! Sausage on a stick! Fishballs on a stick! Noodles. Pancakes, waffles. Dumplings, steamed buns. Noodles. Fried chicken. FRIED PORK FAT! Fruit smoothies and supersweet ice tea galore. And noodles. And after you’re done stuffing your face you can shop for piles of cheap iPhone cases, blingy accessories, fake handbags, shoes, makeup, hippie pants and hipster shirts, knick-knacks, plastic things. Yes, you really do need an iPhone case with rubber bunny ears and a furry tail. And this doesn’t happen once a year at some special overpriced festival like in America, this happens EVERY every night. I love night markets!

Scuba Diving

We came across a good deal for a 5 day dive live-aboard. We were scuba-certified 3 years ago in Belize, with a total of 4 dives under our belt (in other words, the bare minimum.) So we were a little anxious to jump right into a live-aboard, which can only be described as dive, eat, sleep, repeat.

The experience was great! We went to the Similan Islands and Richlieu Rock, some of the most famous dive sites in Thailand. The scuba skills came right back to us with a little coaching. The crew and staff did everything possible to make us comfortable and happy. So happy. You know you have it good when your biggest complaint is that the schools of fish were too thick to see!

Unfortunately we didn’t have an underwater camera so you’ll have to trust our word that the sea life was spectacular. Or find some pictures on the internet.

However doing 3-4 dives per day for 5 days is quite tiring, I think we need a beach vacation after this! :)

Koh Lanta, Thailand

We landed in Krabi airport and immediately transferred to the island Koh Lanta via overpacked van and crossing on 2 ferries.

Immediately we notice a few thing we haven’t seen in a while: It’s clean. The streets aren’t congested with cows and people. Drivers don’t constantly honk their horns. Genders are not segregated, and women are even working, even driving tuk tuks, even wearing shorts! People are friendly and smile. The 7-11 is so bright and clean (up to the highest Asian expectations) and sells green tea and seaweed snacks.

Koh Lanta is a laid-back island, with a few fancy beach resorts, and a high concentration of Swedes for some reason. It’s quite touristy. We are here to relax, and here we are.
Happy New Years

Kerala Backwaters

One of the most popular things to do in Kerala is to cruise the famous backwaters. There are many ways to do this, from the public ferry to chartered boats. We chose one of the more expensive options, a cruise and overnight in a houseboat. It was like having our own private yacht with a crew of 2 for a day! We had 3 meals and tea time aboard and alternated taking naps on deck and enjoying the beautiful scenery. As you can see, there were a lot of houseboats cruising the same waters. Some boats were occupied by a single couple, others packed full with a rowdy group. We decided it would be more fun as a group. Wish you had been there with us!

Periyar Tiger Reserve

We visited the Periyar Tiger Reserve and trekked along the hilly state border of Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Unfortunately it rained and we only caught glimpses of a few sambar deer.

Munnar

The next day we headed for the hills to the tea-growing region of Munnar. The museum there gave us a history of tea plantations in the region and a brief explanation of the tea-making process. We enjoyed walking around the incredible green hillsides. The Munnar hills rise over 1,450 meters (4,760 ft) in elevation and evening became quite chilly!

Merry Christmas

We wish everyone a wonderful Christmas. We have finished India and are currently relaxing on the beaches in Thailand. We’ll be spending our Christmas on a 5 day scuba diving boat trip.Â

photos.caption: Dosa - indian pancake with mashed potatoes inside

body:
Kochi

The next few days we spent in the southwestern state of Kerala. Kerala is the land of exotic spices, the natural medicinal practice of Ayurveda, and lush green landscapes. It is the state with the highest literacy rate, life expectancy, and gender ratio. It has been noted as the least corrupt state in India and had a democratically elected communist government in 1957. The native language is Malayalam, not Hindi. In other words, Kerala is quite distinct from other parts of India.

Our entry into Kerala was the city of Kochi and although we had only half a day to explore, we saw s few sights and ate delicious street fried fish at 50 cents per piece.

Hampi

Hampi is an archaeological area 8 hours east of Goa in the state of Karnataka, situated in a landscape of lush banana plantations and gigantic boulders. It was the capital of the Vijayanagara empire which lasted from 1336 to 1646 AD. Hampi today is a sleepy village full of backpacker types, guesthouses, and souvenir shops. Some very laid-back travelers can spend a week there just chillin’…. There are plenty of ruins to explore over a large area. We spent 3 days wandering through old temples and climbing boulders at a leisurely pace.

Making Chapati

This is so fun. I wish I had a gas stove at home.

Rahul’s Cookery Class

For less than $20 I took a 3 hour cooking class and learned 3 Indian dishes, a flatbread called chapati, and how to make paneer cheese from scratch. It was a fun time meeting other travelers and sharing delicious food that we made. I can’t wait to make paneer at home!

Goa

After 24 hours on a train from Aurangabad via Mumbai, we arrived in paradise.

Goa is a tiny state on the west coast of India that was a Portuguese colony long before the British arrived. It is famous for the beaches. Culturally it feels different: more liberal, more polished (i.e. touristed), and having a greater Christian population as compared to other parts of India. Many homes, churches, and restaurants were gearing up for the Christmas season when we arrived.

The beaches of north Goa, once a true hippy hangout, are notorious for trance parties, Russian revelers, and drugs. We opted for south Goa where life is more laid-back, and found ourselves at Palolem beach, a stretch of golden sand, palm trees, and beach bungalows lining the coast of a calm green Arabian Sea. What a great place to enjoy a drink on the beach and some fish curry! Palolem town is a small street of souvenir shops, restaurants, and internet cafes, with just the right amount of “touristy.” The whole place is so relaxed, you cannot believe it is India! And your day is not complete without a happy beach dog laying on the sand under your sun lounger.

Upon arrival at the beach I was shocked to see tourists wearing shorts, let alone swimsuits.Â The Russians particularly love their tiny swimwear. Even the women! Anyway Goa is one place in India where showing a little skin will not attract the stares and camera phones of groups of creepy men. It was a bit of paradise in India, and a much-needed vacation from our “vacation!”

Bibi-qa-Maqbara

No we didnât visit the Taj Mahal a second time, this is the âpoor manâs Tajâ, Bibi-qa-Maqbara. The mausoleum resembles the Taj Mahal but is mostly made of lime mortar instead of white marble and has no semi-precious stone inlays. It was built by Azam Khan in 1679 for his mother though his frugal father decided that the cheaper materials would be used.

Ellora Caves

The Ellora caves are a similar set of temples like Ajanta but include Jain and Hindu caves along with Buddhist. The caves were created between 600 and 1000 AD.

Ajanta Caves

The Ajanta site is a group of 28 Buddhist temples carved into the solid rock wall of a horseshoe-shaped gorge. The temples were created between 2nd century BC and 650 AD. It is three hours from Aurangabad by car.

photos.caption: storage of plastics on the roofs

body:
Dharavi

Dharavi, Asia’s largest slum, sits in the heart of Mumbai. It contains 1 million inhabitants and was featured in the movie Slum Dog Millionaire.

The definition of a slum is an area where dwellings have been built on someone else’s land, in this case a government landfill in the 1840s. The slum generates hundreds of millions of dollars a year from various industries located within such as recycling and manufacturing. We visited several recycling centers for plastics, aluminum, and paint cans. Next we made our way through the residential alleys, some barely 3 feet wide, trying to catch a glimpse into family homes. Most of the homes have only 1 room and do not have plumbing so most of the 1 million residents use one of the 700 public washrooms available - you do the math. Our tour guide told us that the people are happy living there and wouldn’t move out if given the opportunity. There are even some millionaires (in rupees) that choose to call the slum home. The people have a deep sense of community and consequently there is a very low crime rate.

In addition to slum visits, Reality Tours runs a community center in the slum and 80% of the tour fee goes to fund it. In order not to invade the residents’ privacy we were not allowed to take photos on the tour. Most of these photos are provided by the company.

Jain Temple

We visited the most spectacular Jain Temple made of white marble.Â

Udaipur

This is the last city we visited in Rajasthan. It contains a lake with a palace located on an island made famous by the James Bond movie Octopussy. We couldn’t visit the island because it is a 5-star hotel now and only guests are allowed. The other site we visited was a city palace (on land). It was beautiful with ornate decorations as seen in the pictures.
Happy Thanksgiving from India

Jodhpur, the blue city

Another fort and palace. This one afforded great views of Jodhpur, called the blue city because of a special sky-blue paint used on houses of holy men. Nowadays everyone is allowed to use the blue paint, and so there is a lot of blue.

Jaisalmer, the golden city

A golden sandstone fortress on a hill in far west. People still live within the city walls.

Camel Safari

Khuri desert, west of Jaisalmer, the closest to Pakistan we ever got. We took a camel ride and camped out in the dunes under the open sky. Unfortunately the moon was too bright to see much of stars.

Rat Temple

They say it’s not about worshipping holy rats. There is actually a story behind the lady named Shree Karni Mata. But yeah, rats. Yes its a temple so we went barefoot. Where’s PK when you need him?

Shortly after we arrived in Pushkar, a guide offered to lead us through the Brahma temple and then make a prayer at the holy lake. The guide was friendly and explained the story of Brahma and temple. Then he led us to the lakeside to see the Brahmin priests for a prayer and blessing. He explained that people give donations for the charity and the temple, but we would not be pressured; donations should come from the heart. No pressure, we were assured.

Peter and I were separated to individual priests. So I sat with mine and we had a repeat-after-me session of holy chants. He asked about my family members and we chanted prayers for them.

Then he got to the sell. “How much do you want to donate?” he asked outright. “No pressure. Some people give 1000 rupees, 5000 rupees, some give 10,000 rupees. Americans give American dollars, 50 dollars, 100 dollar….. Give from your heart, for good blessing for your family. Tell me how much will you donate?”

At this point he’s totally pressuring which I really hate, so I said “10 rupees.”

The priest did not even try to hide his displeasure. He the repeated the whole “some people give 1000 rupees… Americans give 50 dollars” spiel. “I am not pressuring you. Please give from the heart. So how much you want to give?”

I said I only had 10 rupees with me because my husband is carrying the money. He then said it was okay to get more money from my husband and I could match whatever donation he made. Okay, I promised to match my husband’s donation.

So when Peter’s priest was finished, we were reunited and he asked for a donation, holding out his metal platter. Both priests and the guide were staring us down hard and Peter pulled out 20 rupees! That really angered them, and they even refused to take the 20 rupees.

The whole experience left us confused and angry. What the hell just happened? Did we offend someone? Not likely, they offended us first by putting on the pressure, we rationalized. It was only later we saw online that this is a normal scam in Puskhar. Just search for “Pushkar scam!” 10,000 rupees my ass!

The funny thing was that even though separated, Peter and I were of the same mind. I’ll give you 10 rupees haha. Actually we are reading online that 10 rupees is fine for a “puja” ritual in India, as it’s just a token for a blessing.

It’s such a shame because Pushkar is a nice little town with an awesome camel fair, only to be ruined by predatory holy men who only want to scam westerners. It really puts up barriers to travelers who want to experience Indian culture and is a shame on India. I wonder why the government doesn’t crack down on this shameful behavior? (Rhetorical question!) Oh, India!

Pushkar

The small town of Pushkar is an important pilgrimage site for devout Hindus. It is centered around a lake that is said to be where Brahma the creator dropped a lotus. They say that here is one of very few temples in the world dedicated to Brahma because, according to the legend his first wife cursed him so he could not have any more temples. Pilgrims come to bathe in the waters and make prayers for the wellbeing of their family. We came to Pushkar during the annual camel fair, a huge event for the region. In addition to vendors and carnival rides, there was the actual business of buying and selling camels. Wow, there were a lot of camels!

Hawa Mahal

The iconic “palace of the winds” built for the royal ladies of Jaipur in 1799. The five story structure earns its name from the many latticed screens and windows that allowed breezes to pass through while keeping the inhabitants shielded from commoners’ eyes. From here the noble ladies could look down upon the outside world.

Jantar Mantar

Jantar Mantar is an observatory in Jaipur that houses many astronomical measuring devices, built by Jai Singh starting in 1728. The instruments are giant sculptures, works of art in their own right. We listened to the audio tour’s lengthy explanations of each of the 16 instruments butÂ basically each one measured the position of some object in the sky.Â

photos.caption: Amber Fort with Jaigur Fort above it.
View of Amber Fort from Jaigur Fort

body:
Amber Fort

Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan state. One of the biggest tourist attractions in Jaipur is Amber Fort (named for the old name of the region, not the color) built by Raja Man Singh I, a king and general of Emperor Akbar in 1592. At the entrance to the fort, one can either walk up the pathway or take a touristy elephant ride. The two routes cross at points and pedestrians definitely need to watch out for elephant crossing. Omg elephants are huge! You do NOT want to be in their path. And remember to keep left on the walkways - you can blame the British for that.

Fatepur Sikri andÂ Jama Masjid Mosque

Akbar moved the capital of his empire from Agra Fort to the site just 23 miles away from 1571 to 1585 in honor of the Sufi saint Salim Chisti. The city was later abandoned due to lack of water in the region. Also of interest nearby is the large historic mosque (Jama Masjid) and inside, the tomb of Salim Chisti. We got a glimpse of Mughal palace life amidst masses of tourists and the usual touts, scams, and trinket sellers.

Agra Fort

Another UNESCO world heritage site, Agra Fort, was held by many rulers, most notably the Mughal emperor Akbar the Great in 1556 CE. Akbar’s grandson, Shah Jahan also ruled from there. It was Shah Jahan who commissioned the Taj Mahal to be built as a tomb for his beloved wife.

Taj Mahal

The Taj Mahal is not overrated, it is really one of the worldâs most beautiful structures. It was built as a mausoleum for third wife of the Mughal emperor in 1632. The building is made of white marble with decorative inlays of semi-precious stones. The craftsmanship is amazing on both a small and large scale.Â

Delhi - Day 2

We visited India’s largest minar, Qutub Minar. It was built in 1192, stands 238 feet tall and was built to celebrate a military victory. The area around the minar contains the ruins of a mosque and tombs.

Delhi Day 1

Our first foray into the craziness that is Delhi! We decided to visit the Jama Masjid, a mosque in old Delhi listed on many a “things to do in Delhi” website. It appeared to be a short subway ride, just 2 stops from New Delhi Metro station, and at a fare of 8 rupees we thought it would be a great little trip. However we never made it to the Metro platform.

New Delhi station was crowded. Like a turbulent sea of wall-to-wall bodies swarming and pushing. What did we expect? We dove in eager to test our swarming skills. It took quite some time and effort to descend into the station and we actually reached the token counter, but by then we realized how would it take to actually board a train? Maybe walking would be quicker. We were wrong!

The streets of Delhi are insane. Crazy like you might have seen on TV: rickshaws, motorbikes, carts, cars, cows, crap, and people. People coming out of every orifice of the city. People begging, people selling crap, people yelling “hello! Hello madam! Hello China! Japanese? Hello hello!” Everyone trying to engage you to sell an expensive tour, trinket, or taxi ride. And honking. The honking is legendary, but Lima has deadened our ears to that already. Feeling lost and realizing it was farther than we had thought, we hailed a bicycle rickshaw. For less than a dollar we could watch the street unfold around us without the fear of getting run over.Â 

At Jama Masjid, some official-looking men tried to charge us 300 rupees to take pictures. We had read about this scheme online so despite their insistence we refused to pay, saying we would not take pictures. They said no cameras or mobile phones were allowed inside, which is crap, as we could see plenty of Indians using their devices. We had to get very assertive. Then they tried to charge me 50 rupees a coverup gown “for modesty.” We called them out on their crap as I happened to be more covered up than most of the local women! We stood our ground and finally we got to visit without the ridiculous extra charges. And screw it, we took pictures anyway, as the locals were doing. While inside we noticed every foreign woman in coverup gowns regardless of what they were wearing underneath. What a racket! (FYI, no need to cover my hair, just look at what the locals are doing and follow suit.)

While we make it sound like we handled it like pros, in reality it was a learning experience for us. We came out ahead financially but it left us drained emotionally. We knew India would not be easy, but how difficult we are only beginning to comprehend.Â
Street Art - Part 2

Street Art - Part 1

Buenos Aires has a lively and active street art scene that covers the entire city. We took a street art tour and learned that graffiti and street art is condoned and even celebrated in the city. Many works are done on public and private properties such as parks, bus stations, homes, and businesses. The works include a wide range of styles from high art, graffiti, stencils, and tags.

Buenos Aires has an obelisk in the heart of the city to celebrate the 400 years of the city’s existence. The obelisk was completed in 1939 and is 221 feet tall.

Mine is bigger.
Argentina is famous for it’s grass fed beef. A giant, delicious steak cost between $4 to $8 (would be over $50 in the USA.) We had to eat our fill before we go to India and become vegetarians.Â

La Recoleta Cemetery

Buenos Aires most famous sight is the Recoleta Cemetery. It began in 1822 and contains 4691 mausoleums of the city’s rich and famous families. The mausoleums are decorated in elaborate styles such as Art Nouveau or Neo-Gothic.

Buenos Aires

After 4 months on the road we reached our final destination in South America - Buenos Aires. Buenos Aires is called the Paris of South America and it didn’t disappoint. The city is full of ornate Beaux architecture (a French style), wide tree-lined boulevards, and cafes. The metro and bus systems were easy and cheap! Natalie’s parents meet us there for a week to explore the capital’s plethora of museums and different neighborhoods.Â

Our first stop in Argentina was the Loki Hacienda in Salta. Loki is a chain of South American party hostels, favored among backpacking Europeans and Australians. The Loki Hacienda in Salta is a bit different than the other Loki hostels, it’s basically a wide semicircle of cabins surrounding a pool and a great clubhouse. As it was a distance outside the city, there was nothing around but fields. After 12 hours in transit we showed up late, in the dark, tired and hungry and were welcomed with all-you-can-eat steak BBQ (for the equivalent of $4!) and a bonfire. It’s true that the Argentinian steak is freaking delicious.

We spent a couple of days relaxing and playing drinking games with a great bunch of people. The rooms were very nice although the pool wasn’t open for the season yet.

For those traveling through Argentina, the Loki Hacienda in Salta is offering free accommodations until December 13, 2013. Seriously, FREE! This opened up a lot of our budget for drinking and we still came out ahead. Go now and get your steak and drink on!

Salar de Uyuni

Day 4

Salar de Uyuni, the largest salt flat in the world. Never ending salt! I made a salt angel. We took crazy pictures. Then at the end of the tour we visited a train cemetery, a remnant of Bolivia’s mining past.

littlepk:

Donât touch my cookie!

Salar de Uyuni

Day 3

Amazing rock formations and more colorful mountains.
That night we stayed in a salt hostel. Everything was made of salt, the walls, the furniture, the floor. No, I didn’t lick the walls.

Salar de Uyuni

Day 2 - Part 2

Salar de Uyuni

Day 2

Today we reached new heights at an elevation of 4,820 m (15,813 feet.) We saw fields of boric acid, colorful lakes with flamingos, windswept ice fields, and steaming volcanic sulfur pits. We soaked in a hot spring and watched groups of delicate vicuÃ±as grazing.

Southwest Bolivia

Day 1

The southwest corner of Bolivia, bordering Chile, has some of the most stunning landscapes on earth. It is a vast and remote region, containing volcanoes, surreal rock formations, and the Salar de Uyuni, the largest salt flat in the world. This was was one of our top experiences in South America!

We took a tour in a 4x4 SUV, and for 4 days we felt like we were in an exciting Toyota Land Cruiser commercial. In fact all vehicles used for tours here are Land Cruisers (I did see a group using the Lexus of the same model).

Our group consisted of Leo, our driver, and his mama Flor, who sat shotgun and cooked all meals for us. They were the kindest people ever! We also had Hector and Ilijana, a wonderful Spanish-Croatian-Australian couple.

At night we stayed in basic cabin-like accommodations with no heat! It was freezing cold, we could feel the chill seeping through 3 wool blankets.

Volcano Soup

K'alapurka, or Karaphurka is a specialty in Potosi, Bolivia. We went to eat it after following a tip that took us to a local restaurant. It is a thick “volcano soup” that is served in a clay bowl with a hot stone inside, causing much steam and bubbling. I’m not sure what it’s made of because I didn’t ask. Potatoes probably, and it had a little bit of fried pork and herbs. Its a hearty soup!

La Paz, Bolivia

La Paz, although at an elevation of 3,640 m (11,942 ft) sits in a valley relative to the surrounding plains. The center of the city lies low, with the sprawl extending up the canyon walls. This means no matter where we go, we have to climb hills in one direction or the other, gasping for breath after a few steps. In contrast to Lima, which sprawls out across the dessert, La Paz is a dense, compact city. Although the streets are narrow and crowded, the drivers in La Paz seem to follow some rules, don’t try to run you down, and honk much less than in crazy Peru. It’s strange how a border can make such a difference in driving culture.

We Survived Death Road

The Yungas road, or “the world’s most dangerous road,"Â connects La Paz to Coroico. The one-lane, unpaved road descends 14,000 feet over 40 miles of mountain-hugging turns. On one side is the mountain and the other side is a cliff that plunges 1,800 feet in places, with no guard rails. Many crosses dot the road where people have died (mostly in automobiles, not bikes.)

I didn’t want to die, but after carefully reading online reviews and searching for terms like "death road bolivia tourist fatalities,” we decided it could be done.

It was freezing cold at the start. I could barely grip the brakes hard enough as my fingers were frozen but gradually as we descended it became hotter and more humid. Amazingly the scenery changed from cold altiplano mountains to lush green jungle. We descended so quickly my ears kept popping. We finally ended at the bottom, where it was warm enough to go for a swim, then after feeding us lunch, the tour drove us back up to La Paz.

Mountain biking is hard on the bones for the uninitiated. It was nonstop bumpy and jarring, a guarantee that every bone in my body would feel it the next day. But in the end we survived, and this blog will continue!

Cholitas Wrestling

A favorite thing to do in La Paz is to watch wrestling! EveryÂ SundayÂ in El Alto, a part of the city high at the top of La Paz, the locals go to the ring. It is for locals and tourists alike: a highly entertaining show with all the pomp and cheese you can expect. The characters are outrageously funny, like the skeleton, the inmate, the tiger, but one character you will not see outside of Bolivia is the cholita.

Cholitas are tough little Bolivian ladies who prefer to wear their traditional indigenous dress: colorful pleated skirts, blouses, and finely embroidered shawls. They wear their hair long and braided, topped with the iconic tiny bowler hat. Their clothes are so beautiful yet these women are are anything but delicate flowers. They represent the proud spirit of the hardy Aymara people who have always inhabited these beautiful and harsh highlands.

So cholitas in the wrestling ring! It was a highly energetic and fun show.

Copacabana: The Bolivian Side of Lake Titicaca

The opposite of Puno, Copacabana is a laid-back, quiet town with a beautiful little harbor. The thing to do here is eat delicious trout and visit Isla del Sol.

Isla del Sol
An hour and a half boat taxi took us to Isla del Sol, or Island of the Sun, in the middle of Lake Titicaca. It is a holy place where, according to Inca religion, the sun god and the first Inca was born. In fact some people today believe the area of Lake Titicaca is a natural vortex, with special earth energy or something.

On arrival we struggled up the “thousand steps,” which I estimated was more like 350, and continued to climb up to a walking path near the top of the island. At 13,400 feet above sea level, there’s hardly any air! The island is sparsely populated, undeniably beautiful, and eerily tranquil. It’s just you, the silence, the bright sun, and the blue water.

We only had a day trip, but if we could do it again we would stay a little longer.

Crossing into Bolivia

We had squandered a little too much time in Peru and seriously needed to move on. It would be hard leaving all the delicious Peruvian food.

We took a bus from Puno, Peru, to Copacabana, Bolivia, which took about 3 hours. The bus dropped us off in Peru to get stamped out and exchange our soles for bolivianos. Then we walked a short distance through a stone arch and we were in Bolivia! Although we had been concerned about obtaining a visa, Bolivian immigration gave us no trouble and very eagerly accepted our $135 pp in crisp US bills.

Puno: Lake Titicaca & Last Stop in Peru

Puno is a noisy, ugly city on the shore of Lake Titicaca, the largest and highest lake in the world. Tourists go to Puno to check out the floating villages in Lake Titicaca. The indigenous people lived on floating islands made of reeds, and supposedly still live that way today, posing for pictures and trying to sell you stuff. Not wishing to partake in gawking at indigenous people and high pressure souvenir sales, we opted out.

For us, Puno was a stopping point before crossing into Bolivia, but we had some time to visit Sillustani. It is an ancient burial site with many chullpas, or stone burial towers dating from pre-Inca times. The site was used by several cultures and finally the Incas. There were several different styles of funeral towers with the Inca being the most impressive rising 12 meters (40 feet) high.

The hillside was sunny and tranquil with views of a blue lake. We shared the site with a few tourists and some local people tending to their llama herd. I don’t think we’ve enjoyed such calm and quiet since entering South America! It was a beautiful last day in Peru and now on the bus to Bolivia!

photos.caption: The oasis can be seen below as well as the steep path out

body:
Colca Canyon

Southern Peru boasts CaÃ±on Colca, a canyon deeper than the Grand Canyon, 6 hours from Arequipa by bus. We went for a 3 day trek down into the canyon and back up. The canyon is scattered with several small villages with basic facilities, so no more camping for us!Â 

On the first day we hiked to the bottom of the canyon, crossing the Colca River and back up to the village of San Juan de Chuccho. The way down was steep and rocky, and afforded us great birds eye views of the villages in the canyon. We stayed in a very basic hostel, in a simple room without electricity and toilets and showers located in an outhouse. As basic as it was, they had delicious banana crepes with caramel for breakfast!Â 

The next day we had a nice walk up through 2 villages perched on the far side of the canyon. Then we descended to the bottom of the canyon again and arrived in Sangalle. Sangalle is called the oasis because it consists of only a few rustic resorts with tantalizing swimming pools. We picked one of them and settled down to swimming and sunbathing for the rest of the afternoon. Our cabin was plastered mud brick and bamboo poles, as were the shower facilities, but everything was clean and comfortable.Â 

The next morning were on the trail by 5:30 am, walking by moonlight at first. This day was 3 hours of zig-zagging straight up the canyon, gaining 1,100 meters. It was very steep and our muscles were aching and shaking by the time to got to the top.Â 

Then we hitched a ride with a random tour group, and on the way back to Arequipa they took us for a dip in the hot springs. The aching and shaking magically disappeared!Â

Arequipa

ArequipaÂ is a large city in Southern Peru that prides itself as Peru’s intellectual capital. It isÂ know as the as white city due to the large number of colonial buildings built with a local white stone called sillar created Â by volcanic eruptions. The main point of interest is the Santa Catalina Convent which was founded in 1580 for rich Spanish girls who didn’t want to get married. The convent was built in the Spanish style and is a city in itself. Each nun had her own house complete with her own servant if her wealthy family provided her with one. In later years the convent was reformed to be more in line with the strict teachings of the Catholic Church and today the number of nuns is down to 25 from a high of 500 in the 1800s.

Ceviche, one of Peru’s most famous dishes.

Ceviche is a seafood dish of raw fish marinated in lime juice, spices, and thinly sliced red onions. The acidic juice chemically “cooks” the fish, so the flesh takes on an opaque quality, but we are still talking raw fish, so fresh is the number 1 priority! Think sashimi with a sour, spicy kick.

Ceviche is served with garnishes of sweet potato and kernels of corn, balancing out the acid with sweet flavors. Fresh fish can be “mixto” with shrimp, octopus, and mollusks.

We love ceviche but it can cost a lot in the US. Is it possible to eat ourselves sick of cecivhe while we are in Peru?

Desert and Oasis

Huacachina is a lagoon in the middle of the desert, outside the city of Ica. The lagoon is small but interesting because it lies in the middle of a real desert with huge sand dunes all around. People come here to swim and sunbathe, maybe row a boat, but the real attraction is the sand dunes. Like all the tourists do, we took a dune buggy ride and went sand boarding.

The dune buggy ride was scary! The drivers are crazy, revving the engine then flooring it over the top of the dune. Then all you can do is hang on and scream as you take a nose dive down the steep side of the dune. The feeling is like a roller coaster but more dangerous (you could die) yet at the same time more secure (only ten feet off the ground).

Sand boarding is more like sand sledding… It’s better to ride it like a sled than attempt using it as a snowboard, since you will not have as much control on sand than on snow. The going is a little slower than on snow, but we accomplished good speeds. The dunes are very high, and the sand is soft and warm.

The combination of dune buggy ride and sand boarding was an awesome adrenaline rush! But one afternoon is good enough for me, I think I’ll stick to solid ground for a while.

Mistura 2013

Speaking of Lima being a gastronomical destination, we had an opportunity to attend South America’s biggest annual food festival, Mistura. This is a 2-week event that showcases Peruvian food and features demonstrations, shows, products, and of course food vendors!

Whole exhibition halls were dedicated to chocolate, another to coffee, ceviche, barbecue, etc. There was plenty of seating (unlike US food festivals) that was cleaned promptly by staff. So nice!

So how do we decide what to eat, when stomach real estate is valuable? Get in the longest line. That’s how we had an encounter with a celebrity chef! Grimanesa Vargas is apparently the lady to go to for anticuchos in Lima. She is a tiny lady, not even 5 feet tall. I was lucky to get a picture as the press and her loyal fans were swarming around her because she walked by as I was picking up my order of delicious, juicy anticuchos. These are skewered, grilled hearts of beef, a popular Peruvian street snack.

In addition to anticuchos, we ended up eating duck in aji sauce, a creamy ceviche, and pachamanca, a kind of Andean mixed roast done in a big hole underground. Throw in some coffee, ice cream, and a churro and we had a square meal!

Also drinks were readily available, with cans of beer going for 2.50 soles (90 cents). We lost count. Dear America, why do you have to outrageously mark up your cheap beers at festivals?

Riding in Combis

The transportation system in Peru, and especially in Lima, is quite interesting! Locally, people travel in mini-buses called combis. They are mostly beat-up large vans retrofitted with rows of seats and handrails. The combis are everywhere and come by literally every 5 seconds so you never have to wait. They drive along major roads inside cities and inter-city, and are labeled with the names of the streets or places they pass. You can figure out the route if you know the place names. The driver does nothing but drive, which can be a harrowing task in Lima. Then there is the “cobrador,” or helper who hangs his body out through the door continuously yelling out names of places. He calls out rapidly like an auctioneer repeating the names of streets in an ever-evolving cadence as the combi drives along its route. I think even if you’re blind you will know exactly where you are based on the progression of the cobrador’s call.

So when you see or hear them call out the route you want, you wave, the combi slows down,and the cobrador opens the door for you, never breaking cadence. You jump in, literally - sometimes they barely stop! Once inside, you pay your fare to the cobrador, most often 35 cents, and when you want to get off you just say so, and the driver slows enough for you to jump out.

People say the combi drivers drive unsafely. In my experience the combis drive aggressively Â in accordance with Lima’s chaotic streets, yet we’ve had taxi drivers that were even crazier. And a combi is bigger than a taxi, and you’re surrounded by squishy people. And from a pedestrian point of view, combis are safer because they are more predictable. We’ve had more close calls with taxis and cars trying to run us over.

Overall a good transportation system? We have benefitted from riding combis as they are convenient, efficient, and cheap. They are privately run and lack strict regulation; some vehicles have seen better days. Pollution, congestion, and safety are problems that shouldn’t be overlooked, but we definitely got where we wanted to go without having to walk 15 minutes and then waiting 20 minutes for a bus or overpriced train that have fights breaking out in them (ahem, DC Metro.)

photos.caption: I stuffed a whole siu mai in my mouth

body:
Eating in Lima

Lima is South America’s foodie heaven.

Peruvian food is one of our favorite cuisines in the world, but we are so over it after eating it for a month straight. As soon as Meredith hit the airport home, we started indulging on international food, starting with Dunkin’ Donuts (don’t judge until you’ve walked in our shoes!) Then we ate Papa John’s pizza (again, no judging.) Then we ate Chinese food, then sushi (twice), then authentic Naples pizza, then Korean barbecue. And at Starbucks I had a manjar blancoÂ latte.

Aside from all the major food chains, Lima offers a wide variety of international cuisine to satisfy a global palate. Start with a real Chinatown (Pueblo Chino). Like Chinatowns in the US, the Chinese don’t actually live there anymore; they live in more wealthy neighborhoods. Peru has a similar history of Chinese, mainly Cantonese, immigrants that have lived here for generations. Also Japanese immigrants; Lima is well known for good sushi.
And so we ate. Unfortunately we ran out of days and didn’t make it to an Indian restaurant. And we didn’t find any pho.

An Evening in Lima

Dinner at Papacho’s
We met a few of our Inca Trail family members at Papacho’s in Lima for one last meal before they had to fly out back home. Papacho’s is a popular burger restaurant owned by Peruvian celebrity chef Gaston Acurio. The burgers were complex, giant, and delicious but left us feeling a little too heavy. We needed to walk it off (as if we hadn’t all walked enough for 4 days already!)

A Walk in the Park: Magical Water Circuit
It’s a nice park full of water features that one can stroll leisurely through, and is especially beautiful at night. There is a small entrance fee. The park features several fountain displays, most of which are dynamic and on a grand scale. There is even a huge fountain that “dances” to music like at the Bellagio in Las Vegas. When we first arrived we glimpsed the end of a light show with a club-like atmosphere, however by the time we got there, that number had ended and the fountains were dancing ballet.

photos.caption: Monument to General Jose de San Martin

body:
Paracas

Three and a half hours south of Lima by bus is the region of Pisco, where pisco comes from! We will get to Pisco soon but our destination was nearby Paracas, a tiny town on the ocean where we could visit the Ballestas Islands and Paracas National Park.

Ballestas Islands
These are a group of small islands with interesting cave formations and natural arches. It is a haven for wildlife, mostly sea birds. Many of the types of animals are seen in the Galapagos: pelicans, boobies, cormorants, Humboldt penguins, and sea lions.

Visiting the islands consists of a 2 hour boat tour. As we waited on the pier, vendors were selling hats “for protection.” We soon came to understand that it was not the sun we needed protection from. As it turns out guano is a valuable resource and is harvested from the islands every few years. Luckily we suffered no direct hits, but spatter is a very real thing, folks.

Candelabra
Carved into the desert rocks is this mysterious geoglyph almost 600 feet tall. It never fades even though it is covered by sand. How old is it? Who put it there? For what purpose? Nobody knows.

Paracas National Reserve
The national park encompasses a lot of sand dunes and dramatic coastlines. The most famous rock arch formation La Catedral (the cathedral) collapsed in a 2007 earthquake. And I saw a sea otter.

Causa Rellena: stuffed mashed potato cakes.

Causa rellena (rellena means stuffed) are mashed potato cakes stuffed with chicken, tuna, or seafood salad, sometimes avocados, tomatoes. The mashed potatoes are creamy and golden due to aji amarillo, a yellow Peruvian pepper that has a lot of flavor and only a little spiciness. They are usually served cold or room temp and often pressed in a round shape and given a nice presentation (I’ve seen one in a heart shape.) I like them because they are beautiful and delicious!

Pisco Sours

Peru’s national drink is theÂ PiscoÂ Sour, comprised ofÂ pisco, sour mix, and whipped egg white.Â PiscoÂ is a type of brandy made from grapes in Peru'sÂ IcaÂ region. The drink is very strong and tasty! I love a goodÂ PiscoÂ Sour but back in the states it would cost $14 or more, while in Peru it’s only 8 soles ($3) - so I am drinking as many as possible. Pisco also mixes well with sprite - that’s called a chilcano.

Pacay

This is the most interesting fruit I have ever encountered. It is a large bean about 1.5 to 2 feet long, and easy to crack open with your fingers. Inside are smooth black seeds the size of almonds, surrounded by fibrous white fluff! The seeds are inedible, but the fibers resemble sweet, damp cotton candy. A bean pod costs 1 sol (35 cents) at the local market.

Lomo saltado (beef stir fry) is Peru’s signature dish made of marinated beef, tomatoes, onions, and french fries. The dish was created by Chinese immigrants who combined their cooking style with local ingredients. The dish is super delicious and I’d recommend anybody with the opportunity to give it a try.Â

Inca Trail - Day 4: The Pinnacle Day

We left camp at 4:30 in the morning to begin the race to the Sun Gate to see a great view of Machu Picchu. It was exciting to finally see Machu Picchu after several days of trekking and zero days of showering. Everyone was abuzz with excitement. After taking lots of pictures from above, we began the descent to the lost city. Right before arriving at the location for the post card photo, the clouds moved in and it began to rain. Our guide tried to wait it out under a shelter for a little while, but the rain showed no signs of letting up so we went ahead with the tour of the site. To be truthful, it was absolutely miserable. Everyone was cold, wet, and tired. We didn’t get to enjoy the ruins and after the tour was over we made our way to our hotel for hot showers.

Inca Trail - Day 3: The Longest Day

The third day was the longest day of the trek. We had to cover over 8 miles through gorgeous mountainous scenery. Unfortunately the day started in the rain but cleared up by lunch time. The first half of the day had some changes in elevation, and we by passed some Inca sites. The second half was mostly flat with great views of the mountains. The scenery had changed from desert highland to lush forest with orchids and ferns. Before reaching our camp we got to enjoy walking through massive Inca terraces overlooking the valley.

Inca Trail - Day 2: The Hardest Day

This day was the most difficult due to massive gains in elevation. We started the day with a 4000 ft ascent up to Dead Woman’s Pass at 13,800 ft. We endured switchbacks and never-ending stairs for 4 hours to get to the top. Natalie was the second one to the top after chewing on coca leaves; Meredith and I languished in the rear of the group.

Inca Trail

The classic Inca Trail hike is a 4-day trek through the mountains, starting in Ollantaytambo and ending in the lost city of Machu Picchu. Nowadays the trail is highly regulated by the Peruvian government and we had to buy our tickets 6 months in advance because they sell out quickly. Only 500 people are allowed on the trail per day, of which roughly 200 are trekkers (the rest are porters and guides). The trek is pretty tough due to the high elevation and steep ascents. It was more bearable due to the awesome tour company we went with. We didn’t have to worry about the tents, food, or cleanup, and we even got morning wake-up calls with hot coca tea in our tents. Our group consisted of 12 other trekkers from the USA, Germany, Mexico, and Canada. The group was great and we adopted the team name “Qori Inti Family” (Golden Sun Family.) We shared some great experiences over the next 4 days.

Day 1: The Easiest Day

The first day was so easy, mostly flat and we walked by several Inca sites. We arrived to an already set-up campsite and a delicious hot meal complete with appetizers, soup, stewed chicken, rice, and vegetables.
I’ve heard leaving commentsÂ on the blogÂ is difficult, here is how to register with facebook to be able to comment.
The Sacred Valley of the Incas - Part 2

The Sacred Valley of the Incas - Part 1

The sacred valley was a very important agricultural heartland of the Incas, near Cusco, where fertile lands produced a great bounty of maize (corn), potatoes, and quinoa. There are a multitude of Inca sites. We hired a private guide and driver for the day, which was well worth the money. We arrived at each site ahead of the tour bus crowds and didn’t have to wait around for slow people!

Animals
We took a stop at an animal rescue center and got to see animals! Of course there were llamas and alpacas, and a skinny relative called the vicuÃ±a, which runs wild in the Andes. It is featured on the Peruvian flag. The vicuÃ±a purportedly produces the softest wool in the world, albeit slowly, and due to their undomesticated nature are highly susceptible to poaching. A vicuÃ±a wool scarf can cost over $1500 USD. Also featured in the rescue center were some massive Andean condors, a multitude of birds, wild cats, and other random animals.

At the next stop we were given a large bouquet of grass, instructed to hold it tightly, and walk through the llama/alpaca enclosure. Suddenly hungry camelids were all up in my face! They knew what’s up. Yeah it was touristy but it was fun!

Pisac
We visited the town of Pisac for the local market and some Inca ruins. At the market we helped Meredith bargain for an alpaca wool blanket, for which according to the tour guide, we got a fair price. Haggling is so much work! The Inca ruins at Pisac were nice examples of agricultural terracing. It took some effort to climb up the stairs to the residential areas, as we were still acclimatizing to the elevation.

Guinea Pig Lunch
Lunch was cuy al palo, or guinea pig on a stick! We had asked our guide to take us to eat guinea pig, the way the locals like it. And this is why we loved having a private tour- we stopped in a small town known for its roadside stands with local women roasting skewered guinea pigs over charcoal. Â Seated at a plastic table on plastic chairs like the locals, we chowed down on a crispy little animal stuffed with local herbs! The skin was crispy, somewhat like roasted pork skin, but the meat is difficult to describe. I can’t compare it to anything familiar, maybe pork, but not chicken, texture like duck, somewhat stringy. Not bad, and I would like to try eating it again. But one is quite small, divided between Peter, Meredith, and me. Next time I want my own! They say on your birthday, you get to eat a whole cuy.

Ollantaytambo & Chinchero
Another site we visited was Ollantaytambo, a settlement for wealthy Incas and priests built on the mountain featuring terraces, a temple, and extensive irrigation. There was a lot of fine stonework (the best stonework was for the wealthy and the religious, naturally.) Ollantaytambo is the starting point of the classic 4-day Inca trail to Machu Picchu, so we would be back in a few days.

We also visited Chinchero, a village high on a agricultural plain above the sacred valley which featured great Inca terraces and an old Catholic church built upon the Inca foundations.

photos.caption: Church built of top of the Inca's temple of the Sun, Qorikancha.

body:
Cusco, The Capital City of the Inca Empire

For the Inca, Cusco was the center or navel of the world. It served as their capital until the arrival of the Spanish conquistadores in 1534.

After Cusco was conquered, the Spanish destroyed the city and used the Inca stones for the foundations of their own buildings. Thus the architecture of Cusco is symbolic of Peru’s history, colonial buildings built on Inca foundations.

Some of the amazing stonework remains intact in the Qorikancha, located near the center of town. The original Qorikancha was an important temple for the sun god Inti. The Spanish built the Church of Santo Domingo over the Inca temple, destroying much but keeping the foundations, and also preserving some of the original Inca rooms inside. The sophisticated stonework techniques of the Incas proved resilient to earthquakes.

We also visited some archaeological sites around Cusco. The most interesting was Saksaywaman (pronounced sexy woman for the gringos), a pre-Inca site built of massive stones. It was used was a fortress to protect Cusco as well as a ritual site.Â

photos.caption: Typical Street, colonial buildings built on top of inca stones

body:
Cusco, # 1 Tourist Destination in South America

Cusco, elevation 3400 m (11,200 ft) is a tourist destination. The city has an obviously clean and polished feel compared to other places in Peru. There are so many tourists of all nationalities, from the casual family and group tourists, to those more seemingly hardcore backpackers. Everywhere you go someone is taking a picture with a massive camera, with a Peru guidebook tucked in their back pocket. There are beautifully dressed Quechua women with baby alpacas ready to pose for a picture for 1 sol. There are souvenirs and tour bookers galore! There are nice hotels, the lobbies of which we peered into longingly and imagined ourselves in soft linens, heated rooms, and bathtubs. (lookin’ at you, Mariott Cusco,Â do you have any budget rooms?)

We were able to find some less commercial parts of town for cheap almuerzos. You just can’t beat a hearty 2-course lunch for 4 soles ($1.50). I highly recommend Mercado San PedroÂ for a taste of the local market. Also try the regional pork specialties, chicharron (delicious fried fatty pork) and adobo (hearty pork soup).

We also splurged at a nice steakhouse for alpaca steaks! The restaurant was exceptional and our alpaca filets came out rare on a sizzling stone for us to finish as we desired. Alpaca is very tender and tasty, like steak but less beefy. I would like to eat some more!

The ChocoMuseo in Cusco

Due to a series of flight delays, Meredith arrived midday and exhausted, so I found a great low-impact activity for us, a chocolate making workshop!

The ChocoMuseoÂ is a museum, chocolate factory, cafe, and workshop with a few locations in cacao growing regions of Latin America. We attended the 2 hour “beans to bar” workshop where we learned about chocolate-making from scratch. We got to roast, shell, and grind cacao beans, and finally create our own flavored chocolates in molds. It was educational, fun, and delicious! Chocolate with cinnamon was my favorite combination, and Peter liked chocolate with ginger. We took home a bag of our chocolate creations, but they didn’t last long.

photos.caption: Waiting for the strike to end

body:
We took a 24 hour bus ride from Lima to Cusco, which wasn’t as bad as it sounds. The Cruz del Sur bus company is a great way to go. The VIP seats are large, comfortable, and fully reclining, with blankets and pillows, personal entertainment systems and wifi; everything I imagine first-class seats on an airplane to be, minus the alcohol. They served us hot meals and even held a bus-wide bingo game. As we neared Cusco, we had a little delay due to a strike blocking the road, stopping quite a long line of traffic. Not sure what it was all about, but we got out and stretched our legs in the warm sun for an hour and watched the local ice cream vendor take advantage of a large captive audience.

So eventually we arrived in Cusco, the capital of the Inca empire and #1 tourist destination in South America.

We were very excited because we were just days from starting the Inca Trail, and Peter’s sister Meredith would be joining us soon from the USA with much needed supplies like Reese’s peanut butter cups.
We ate an Andean delicacy, cuy (guinea pig), in the countryside! Cuy Cuy Cuy!

Lake Churup Hike

Lake Churup is a popular day hike from Huaraz because it is easy to get to, a good moderately difficult hike, offers stunning scenery of snow-capped mountains and lake, and includes a little amateur rock climbing experience.

We departed at 8 am and met a pair of very cool Londoners (hello Jim and Rebecca!) getting on the bus who would become our hiking companions for the day. The overcrowded bus dropped us off in the town of Llupa (pronounced Yupa), where we walked a leisurely hour to Pitec, barely a settlement and the start of the trail.

The trail was steep! Over all we gained 600 M (2,000 feet) in elevation over 2.5 km, and it took us almost 3 and ½ hours. Long-legged Jim and Rebecca had left us long ago (yeah Peter and I are slow…) and we continued our way up the steep and rocky path, stopping many times to rest and take in the amazing views. Every time we stopped I looked behind and marveled at how far below we were just minutes ago.

The final stretch of the hike had us climbing rocks! There were 3 sections that had steel cables anchored into the rock to assist climbers. Having no previous experience, we were intimidated by what seemed like a vertical rock wall. But after studying the rocks for a while, it seemed like a path opened up! A handhold here, a foothold there, the way presented itself slowly. A few rock scrambles more and at last there was Lake Churup: a beautiful reward for an amazing hike. Vale la pena!

At the lake we met up with the Brits again. Then very quickly the clouds moved in and it started to hail little styrofoam balls, like Dippin’ Dots. Time to get back, fast! The return was wet and slippery. There was a lot of controlled “bum sliding” down rocks, but soon we escaped the weather and made it back to Llupa, hoping to catch a bus back home. Then we were told by an old man passing by that there would be no bus… so what do?

Of course we got on the back of a pickup truck and had our first South American hitchhiking experience! In addition to us foreigners, the driver picked up a few local women in traditional dress and we all hung on and bounced around together on the dirt and rocky road, trying not to sit our butts down on the truck bed (is that brown stuff fertilizer or dirt?) The driver dropped us off near the center of town and refused the few soles we offered him.

It was a great day and I loved climbing the rocks. I’ll be looking to try some more in the future. Peter on the other hand hated it!

Llanganuco Lakes

In the HuascarÃ¡n national park nestled between the two highest peaks in Peru lies Llanganuco, a pair of lakes named Chinancocha and Orconococha. We took a combi van from Huaraz to the town of Yungay, where we hired a taxi to ascend the rocky, winding road into the national park. After a brief stop at the national park entrance to pay the 5 soles fee, we continued on to the lake. The scenery was awe-inspiring!

I should mention the flies because no one else has. Nowhere online did anyone mention the giant flies that buzz around these lakes. They are loud and annoying and will land on your head, face, ears, camera lens. Wear a hat or hoodie!
Who left all these sacks of gee-nee peegs out here? Squee!

photos.caption: view of the outskirts of Huaraz
country home with a political banner painted on the outside

body: One of our day hikes was from Huaraz to the ruins of Wilcawain. It took us 3 hours at a mild incline, walking through dusty mountain villages and fields. The archaeological sites of Wilcawain and Ichic Wilcawain are remnants of the Wari people who lived in the area around 500 to 900 CE. The Wari practiced ancestor worship and built large mausoleums of stone. It is believed some Wari moved down from the mountains and merged with the descendants of Moche, eventually creating the ChimÃº culture that we saw in Chan Chan.

Huaraz

We are now in Huaraz, elevation 3052 m (10,013 ft). Before arriving we had taken acetazolamide tablets to prevent altitude sickness, and Peter is happy to report no problems this time! The night bus from Trujillo was comfortable and took about 6 hours.

Huaraz is a nice mountain city nestled below the HuascarÃ¡n National Park, The area is a magnet for trekkers and climbers due to the Cordilerra Blanca, a snow capped mountain range containing some of the highest peaks in the Andes. The tallest peak in Peru, HuascarÃ¡n Sur is 6768 m (22,205 ft.) As a lifelong East-coaster, I have never seen snow capped mountains such as these! So incredible!
huaraz.peru.craigslist.org

body:
Archaeological Sites near Trujillo

The region around Trujillo has several pre-Columbian archaeological sites. We stayed at the nearby beach town of Huanchaco, which was a quieter and more relaxed place than Trujillo.Â 

The Moche Civilization: Huaca de la Luna

The Moche civilization spanned from 100 to 700 CE and populated the river valleys of the northern Peru coast. It was a society based on agriculture using complex irrigation systems, fishing, and was known for its elaborate ceramic work.

The Moche built structures using mud brick, which was sufficient for the desert climate. However every 3-7 years the El NiÃ±o phenomenon brings unseasonable rains which damage the desert ecosystem in northern Peru. During El NiÃ±o, the local agriculture suffered, the coastal bounty was reduced, and the dry mud buildings of the Moche were damaged by rains. During these times, the Moche believed that the gods were angry with them, and developed a ritual human sacrifice to appease him. The temple, Huaca de la Luna, played an important role in these large sacrificial rituals.Â 

One of the theories of the downfall of the Moche was that a super El NiÃ±o occurred around 536-594 CEÂ which lasted 30 years, eroding the Moche faith that sacrifices would dispel ruinous weather. The Moches began to abandon their faith and their temples, but continued to live in the region, eventually giving rise to the Chimu culture.

The ChimÃº Civilization: Chan Chan

The ChimÃº culture, which was a continuation of the Moche, dominated the northern Peru region from 850 to 1470 CE. Chan Chan was their capital city. Like the Moche, structures were built with mud bricks, which did not hold up well to time and rain. Much of the site we visited had been restored by archaeologists.Â 

In Chan Chan, there were massive rectangular palaces, or mini-cities surrounded by high walls with only one entrance. Each palace was built for one ruler, and when he died it became his tomb. The next ruler and all the inhabitants built a new palace to live in. Thus each palace was inhabited successively. As to be expected, the common folk lived outside of the palaces, separate from the elites.Â 

The Chimu were conquered by the Incas in 1470 by Tupac Yupanqui, only 50 years before the Spanish arrived.
Picarones are fresh deep-fried dough rings drizzled in a spiced molasses syrup. They are a popular street food in Peru, served hot from the fryer. They only cost 1 sol (35 cents!)

photos.caption: temple on top of the main structure

body:
This post is very late. Before we left Ecuador, we visited the archaeological site of Ingapirca north of Cuenca. It was a small Inca town populated by the local people called the CaÃ±ari. The Incas believed they originated from Lake Titicaca Â in southern Peru and had conquered the CaÃ±ari in the 1400s. When Francisco Pizarro of Spain arrived in Peru in 1532, he conquered the Inca with 160 soldiers and the help of the local subjugated people like the CaÃ±ari. One fun fact about the CaÃ±ari, they were a matriarchal Â society where the women were the leaders of society and held the positions like shaman and politician.

-peter
Dog on woof spotted in the mountains near Huaraz, Peru

We normally avoid McDonaldâs at home but itâs a welcomed treat after traveling for 2 months. It was so delicious and McDonaldâs has real ketchup! All the ketchup weâve had in Ecuador and Peru is way off. When my sister comes to visit us in 2 weeks, sheâll have to bring me some real Heinz ketchup.

-peter

Border Crossing #1: Ecuador to PerÃº

At 7:15 am we boarded the Pullman Sucre bus in Cuenca, and then we transferred directly to a CIFA company bus in Huaquillas. The scenery changed dramatically as we descended from Ecuadorean highlands to the Peruvian north coast- from the high mountains, through lush humid banana plantations, to dry dessert scrubland, and the beach-lined coast.

On CIFA we crossed the border and were herded into immigration control. Everything was in one building and straightforward- stand in one line to get stamped out of Ecuador, then stand in another line to get stamped into PerÃº. Then we got back on the bus and arrived in MÃ¡ncora around 5:30 pm (total transit 10 hours.) We checked into the Loki party hostel. It’s time to play vasos voladoros y pong de cerveza, eat ceviche and lomo saltado! (The sushi was fresh but the flavors kinda weird)

Â¡Hola PerÃº!

Loving my summer cut

If anyone else is missing PK as much as we are, you can follow this blog at http://pk.worldtravelblog.com

I finally got my first taste of Ecuadorian crabs. When we were at the beach several weeks ago we tried to find a crab shack where we could chow down on a dozen crabs but to no avail. The other day we passed by a seafood restaurant and I got the crab soup for lunch. The soup was yummy but I figured out why Ecuadorians donât eat crabs by the bushel, thereâs not enough meat in them! It was so much work for a tiny bit. So now Iâm left craving some meaty Chesapeake Bay blue crabs.

-peter

We are in Cuenca for the week. Itâs the third largest city in Ecuador, located in the southern mountain region (elevation 8400 feet) and has a population of ~ 300,000. The main highlight is the historic city center which is a UNESCO world heritage site. An interesting note, a beautiful new cathedral was built in the 20th century but couldnât be completed because the structure could not support the weight of the towers. There is a large crack in the front of the cathedral from the incomplete towers.

-peter
On the road to Cuenca

Hiking around near BaÃ±os. The road up the mountain past Iluchi, and the footbridge at Los Sauces. The last picture is the volcano Tungurahua puffing up smoke (picture taken from our hostel.) The volcano became more active the day we left BaÃ±os!
Here’s a picture of a dog on a roof (woof). It’s a pretty common sight here, so I might make a photo series of them.

I’m finally feeling better after my bout with stomach issues. We are in a little town centered around volcanic hot baths which we enjoyed for several hours with our new friends. Today we hiked to see some great views of the town.

-Peter

photos.caption: AM I A ALPACA OR A LLAMA???

body:
Quilotoa

After leaving Peter, I rode standing on the back of an open truck to Quilotoa with some hostelmates, including the 2 Belgian women. The hour drive was hair raising but even more stunning in the open air. We arrived in the village of Quilotoa (elevation 12,821 feet) and it was freezing cold up there!

Quilotoa is famous for its crater lake formed 800 years ago. Local legend says that it has no bottom. Wikipedia says it is 820 feet deep. Walking up to the ledge and viewing the perfect blue green lake below was one of the most stunning sights I have ever seen!

One of the Belgian ladies, Ariane agreed to hike with me down to the lake. Many people hike down, about 30 minutes to descend 1312 feet, and ride a horse back up because the trail is very steep and sandy. Ariane did not want to ride a horse back up and I was not about to an older lady make me look weak! So we both made the hike back up! It was most difficult in the deep sand, climbing two steps upward and sliding one step down. I could taste the dust in my mouth and feel it in my contact lenses. It took double the time to reach the top. Along the way we were passed by fleet-footed indigenous men, women & children in beautiful traditional dress (for the women this means skirts, stockings, and little black leather shoes) making their way down and up with ease.

But when we finally made it up to the top, I felt awesome! Ready for the Inca Trail! YEAH!

The 1 PM bus was there as promised and we were back in Latacuga by 3:30 PM, where I found Peter alive and feeling better, but still quite exhausted.

And so this ends our journey into the extreme highlands for now. Alas there will be no hiking in Cotopaxi, and who the hell knows what’s going to happen in Cuzco next month, but we are moving on to BaÃ±os (de Agua Santa), elevation 5955 feet.

In ChugchilÃ¡n, Peter went straight to bed and stayed there. CC: headache, nausea, irritability, fatigue. He didn’t get up for dinner. He didn’t get up for breakfast. He didn’t even touch his laptop so you knew something was wrong. DX: altitude sickness. This was worse than just mild SOB! He could barely stand up. The only way out was down. And we had only just gotten here! :(

We decided to send Peter back to Latacunga (elevation 9200 feet) via private tran$port while I would spend the morning seeing Quilotoa. I could catch the 1 PM bus back to Latacunga in time for dinner. Two Belgian ladies were doing just that, so I had some traveling companions. Good luck Peter, see you in Latacunga!

Saquisili Market

From Quito, we took a bus south to Latacunga, the capital of Cotopaxi province. From there one can explore the popular hiking destinations of Quilotoa and Cotopaxi Volcano.

We arrived in time to catch the Thursday market at Saquisili, about 20 minutes north of Latacunga. The Saquisili market is one of the largest traditional markets in Ecuador, and much less touristy than the famous Otovalo Market. It is a place where real Ecuadorians buy and sell produce, animals, clothing and furniture. The most interesting part was the live animals! There were crates of chickens, pens of ducks, turkeys, giant rabbits, guinea pigs, and the usual sheep, alpacas, and cows. There were boxes full of puppies and sacks of kittens! We spent only a short time there but I bought some useful items such as fleece pants and carabiners.

Next we boarded a bus for 3 hours of scary switchbacks and awesome mountain views (I love highlands!) to the small village of ChugchilÃ¡n, elevation 10,500 feet, our base camp for hiking in the Quilotoa area.

Peter started feeling sick…

Canoa

We spent 3 days in Canoa. It was off-season so the town was pretty quiet and the weather was windy and somewhat overcast. The ocean was warm enough. We ate a lot of seafood and chased little crabs on the beach.
Ecuador’s beaches are far from pristine, which kept our beach walks interesting. Over all not a bad place to visit, maybe better during high season due to the weather.

Next we go back to the mountains for some hiking!

Peter wanted to go to the beach, because Ecuador has some great Pacific beaches, but which to choose? We heard about Canoa, a laid back little beach town with no ATMs popular with surfers. That really seemed to appeal to Peter, so off we go!

There is a direct overnight bus from Quito to Canoa though the Reina del Camino bus company. The Reina Del Camino bus station in Quito is located on 18 de Septiembre west of El Ejido park; direct service from Quito to Canoa costs $10.

The bus departed Quito at 10:45 PM. The seats were comfortable and reclined more than an average coach seat, however the road was a winding mountain descent full of hairpin turns and speed bumps. We tried to sleep lurching back and forth with the bus, trying not to imagine what the road might look like if we peeked around the window curtain into the dark abyss.

Around 1:30 AM I heard the call of nature. Everyone on the bus was âasleep" and I peeked back at the advertised toilet at the back of the bus. Doubtful, I tried to go back to sleep. Then nature called 911. I pushed Peter aside and made my way to the back of the bus. Padlocked?! At high risk of soiling my pants, I ran to the front of the bus and knocked on the driverâs door. “Â¿No puedo usar el baÃ±o?” I managed to whimper. The driver wordlessly motioned to his helper who had a bunch of keys. Unfortunately the bathroom door would not latch so the helper had to unlock the door for me and hold it closed while I took care of my call. The bus continued to pitch back and forth.

After the toilet incident I went back to attempting sleep and everything ran smoothly until 4:30 AM.

“Â¡CANOA!” “Â¡CANOA!”

We have arrived at the beach!
