Save yourself $125 by getting your Yellow Fever Vaccine in Ecuador.

Yellow Fever is an “exotic” disease in the USA, therefore it is generally not covered by insurance. The vaccine is only available in authorized clinics worldwide, because you will receive an international certificate of immunization. Some countries require this certificate as proof of vaccination. Consult a travel medical professional to find out if yellow fever vaccine is needed.

A travel clinic in Washigton, DC offered the vaccine for $135. In Ecuador it is free to the public, plus a $10 fee for the certificate.

How to:
Centro de Salud No.1 - In historic Quito on Rocafuerte st. & Venezuela st. (to the east of he building with the yellow arch spanning Venezuela st). Go up to 2nd floor you will see a room at the top of the stairs with a sign for “vacunas.” Ask for the “vacuna contra fiebre amarilla.”
Please note this is a live vaccine so there are some contraindications. The nurse did not ask me any medical questions!

Details: bring your passport, it is a quick and painless jab in the arm. Get your injection first then go to 1st floor to trade your receipt for the official certificate of vaccination*. I believe the center is open from 8:30 am to 4:00 pm M-F.

*They were out of international certificates at Centro de Salud No.1 so we had to go to Centro de Salud No.2 - it is located very far west of ColÃ³n trolley station, a 30+ minute walk west on ColÃ³n st then continue west uphill on Humberto Albornoz st, turn right on Lizarazu and go to the bottom of the hill.
Details: we had to give them color copies of our passport and vaccination receipt.

photos.caption: We hiked up the volcano Sierra Negra to look at the massive caldera. The volcano is one of the most active in the Galapagos, with its last eruption in 2005.

body: more galapagos photos

We’re back from the Galapagos Islands. The Galapagos is a group of volcanic islands in the Pacific Ocean straddling the equator off the coast of Ecuador. The islands are special because they are relatively new volcanic islands, the ecology of which has evolved from barren lava rock without the influence of humans. Each island is slightly different and contains unique plants and animals. The observations Charles Darwin made of the islands during his visit in 1835 incited his theory of natural selection, and he went on to write On the Origin of Species.

We spent 6 days on the Grand Odyssey Yacht. The boat did not disappoint! It was large and luxurious, and Peter got his coveted hot tub on deck. We got to know 14 other passengers from around the world, (USA, Canada, Texas, Germany, Hong Kong, Australia) and an indulgent crew.

The cruise took us to the following islands: Isabela, Fernandina, Santiago, and San Cristobal, where we hiked, snorkeled, kayaked, shot animals (pictures), and tanned to a shade of golden brown. Peter used a lot of sunscreen; I used a lot of meclizine.Â 

The islands are covered in flowing ribbons of black lava rock and pristine beaches lined with mangroves.Â During our trip we saw marine iguanas, giant tortoises, sea turtles, penguins, sea lions, sharks, fish, a whale, and birds. The animals evolved without predators so they are not afraid of humans. You can walk right up to them. For example the blue-footed boobie bird lays eggs and raises chicks directly on the beach without building a nest. The sea lions in particular are intelligent and playful like doggies; it wasn’t uncommon for them to swim circles around a person snorkeling!

We have a ton of pictures from the islands and we will be posting a small selection on this blog. The rest of the pictures will be uploaded to Flickr but the internet is super slow here so it might be a while before the album is complete, we’ll post the link when it’s ready.

We have been in the Galapagos for 2 days on the island of Santa Cruz. We have hung out on the beach, swam in a grotto, and seen lots of iguanas. Today we are getting on a boat for a 6 day cruise. We’ll be posting again when we return to civilization. Ciao.
-Peter
We are going to the Galapagos tomorrow and I can’t wait to be at sea level. We are taking a 6 day cruise around the islands on an awesome boat that has 2 hot tubs!
Pichincha: itâs like Scotland, without the bloody midges! (Elevation 15,000 feet)

photos.caption: Us with our spanish profesor Luis
the view from on top of the monument

body:
The Equator and The Summer Solstice
For the last day of spanish class Professor Luis took us on a field trip to the Mitad del Mundo, or the “middle of the world” which is about 1 hour north of Quito by bus. We tookÂ the city bus which was only possible under the guidance of Luis, and it cost only 48 cents! To hire a taxi round trip would have cost about $40.
Our first stop was a volcanic crater Pululahua. We stopped by to look down at the lush valley.Â 
Friday, June 21 was the summer solstice. This means the earth’s northern hemisphere is tilted to the max towards the sun. For those at home in the north, it is your longest day, and the start of summer. For us on the equator the summer solstice simply meant that the sun has traveled the furthest north of the equator. This is mildly interesting, as we visited the actual equator line.
On the Equator line there is an entertaining little museum called IntiÃ±an. We had an English speaking guide who taught us a little about some of the indigenous people of Ecuador, includingÂ shrunken heads, poison darts, and fish that swim up your penis. Then we we brought to the equator line where we observed some equatorial “phenomena,” including the infamous drain trick demonstrating the Coriolis effect. Does water drain clockwise in the northern hemisphere and counter clockwise in the southern hemisphere? When a sink was placed directly on the line, we saw the water drain directly down without swirling. When moved north of the equator line, the water drained in a clockwise rotation, and counter clockwise south of the line! It was quite entertaining, but a it’s just simple gimmick you can find out about on the Internet.Â 
Next we visited the historic Mitad del Â Mundo Monument, which marked the equator as calculated before the age of GPS. Using only instruments available at the time, early geographers calculated this line and a monument was placed there in 1939. It is only 240 meters from the actual equator, which is not bad at all!

photos.caption: Inside the roof of Quito's Basilica

body:
On Saturday we visited Quito’s Basilica which was built in 1927. Instead of Â the normal demon gargoyles the church has animals from the Galapagos like turtles, iguanas, and birds. We climbed up the church to see the great view but we didn’t go all the way up because it was very scary. One of the ladders on the outside of the roof of the church was alongside a flying buttress. - No thanks!Â 

After our brush with death, we went to the Presidential Palace in the heart of the historic center. Not to much to say about it, it’s a beautiful colonial palace with grand rooms and pretty courtyards. And nope we didn’t get to see the president :(

Here we have a surprise chicken foot in a flavorful broth with cilantro, onions, and carrots! I love me some chicken feet.

Let’s revisit food in Ecuador.

The chicken here tastes really good! I can taste a delicious difference between our factory farmed hormone-grown flavorless white protein and real chicken. Whether in a soup, stew, empanada, or a-la-brasa (rotisserie), I really enjoy the chicken here more than I ever have in the USA, from wing to foot.
Cupsi tiene 5 meses. Es un perrito malcriado.
Almurezo: Three Course Fixed Price Lunch with Fresh Juice for $2. Everywhere, Every Day. Juice of the Day: Fresh Guava!

We are now staying with a family in Quito while we take classes at Simon Bolivar Spanish School. The school is very friendly and professional and arranged the home stay for us. We have class for 4 hours a day for 2 weeks. Our teacher is excellent and fun to work with. Its truly an intense immersion experience, and I feel like I’m learning Spanish FOR REAL! (Â¿En serio?)

The family we are staying with has a beautiful clean house, a bird, some fish, and Cupsy. The mother Gloria is the nicest lady in Quito! She speaks to us in Spanish, gently corrects our grammar, and makes wonderful meals for us. Two of her adult daughters live in the house but are working, so we see them in passing.

Meanwhile a local travel agency got us a great last-minute deal for a Galapagos cruise! As expected, prices were 30-50% less than what we would have paid if we had booked ahead in the US. More to come on this, but I just want to say that last-minute deals are especially available for “luxury class” boats. Delightfully, our planned budget was more than enough, so Peter will get to fulfill his dream of lounging in a hot tub on a luxury catamaran in the Pacific Ocean… We are headed to the Galapagos in 2 weeks!

My hosting company is having some problems and the website is up mas o menos (more or less). Here are some pictures from the national museum we visited a couple of days ago. The museum has precolumbian and colonial artifacts.

Otherwise we are keeping busy with spanish school and salsa dancing.

Â¡Hasta Luego!

I Forgot to Pack my Skinny Jeans and Â Stiletto Boots

I can’t help but notice that the women of Quito take pride in taking care of their appearance. They are quite fashionable. The predominant women’s outfit is tight jeans, layered tops, jacket, accessories, and sky high heels. Leggings are popular too. Hair is long and beautiful and makeup is a must. The makeup may get a little heavy and fashion a bit trashy, but it is obvious they take the time to care about their look. I appreciate this, as it makes people watching very fun.

So obviously we stick out as tourists, the Chinita-con-Gringo wearing T-shirts and comfy sandals. I packed several hiking pants but no mascara. I remind myself that whatever I own I have to carry, but I am tempted to buy a pair of jeggings and high heels. Pity me for a minute as I only have my hiking shoes and a pair of sandals. A girl’s gotta have shoes.

The first day we walked from our neighborhood La Mariscal through a large, lovely park El Ejido to the historic old city center. The old city center is typical of the beautiful Spanish colonial streets seen throughout Latin America. We took a taxi back to our hostel for a few dollars. The second day we managed the bus-tram like a local downtown (easy) for 25 cents. Its like a trolley, but actually a bus that drives in its own separate lane and stops at limited stations. I think it’s genius and cheap and wonder why we can’t have this on Georgia Ave. already instead of waiting 10 years for fancy trolleys. Anyway, along the way Peter haggled me a watch from $12 to $8, although in retrospect the cheap Chinese plastic is probably worth less. By the third day we had taken a city bus back from visiting a hilltop park El Panecillo. Atop the hill was a giant statue of Virgin Mary and spectacular views of Quito.

Lunch today was boiled potatoes in broth with a large slab of gelatinous pork skin, for $1.50. It was what all the locals at the market were eating, and not bad, though rather bland. Actually most of the food in Quito has been rather bland. At first I was excited over a pile of fried pork on top of fried potatoes, rice and corn but it got boring very quickly. A lot of carbs here- it’s possible to see potatoes y rice y plantains y corn, all on one plate! There’s a popular thing called “salchipapas,” which is a platter of hot dogs and fries. I’m in no hurry to try it. There is ceviche, however I prefer the Peruvian version.

Oh by the way no hablo espaÃ±ol. Peter knows a little and I can memorize words and blurt them out them randomly. We have been getting around with a lot of pointing and randomness, and it’s not too bad.Â TomorrowÂ we start Spanish classes for 2 weeks and move from a hostel to a homestay.

- natalie
Our first day wandering around the old colonial center of Quito.Â
I’m going to miss you so much!

We have said our goodbyes and moved out of our house. Here’s to our friends and family: we will miss you! It’s only for one year but we will miss birthdays and weddings, neighborhood restaurants, raccoons on the roof, hanging out watching internet videos, dinner parties, wine festivals, spa trips and shopping sprees.

And we will miss our little PK.

Hello friends, family, and random internet people,

Five or so years ago Natalie and I decided that we would travel the world. Itâs been years of planning and our departure is finally here! In twelve months our RTW trip will span ten countries:Â Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Argentina, India, Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, Laos, and China.

It’s hard the believe in the next year we will experience the Galapagos islands, Machu Picchu, the Taj Mahal, Angkor Wat, and the Great Wall of China.
